title: 111_s298
content:
The Financial Markets Commission Act of 2009 establishes the Financial Markets Commission to investigate the causes of the financial and economic crisis in the United States. The Financial Markets Commission Act of 2009 establishes a 7-member Commission with appointments from various government leaders and the Federal Reserve Chairman. Members should have expertise in regulation, finance, economics, and housing. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of the 7-member Financial Markets Commission are elected by the members, with the requirement that they cannot be from the same political party. If 4 or more members are appointed within 45 days of the Act, they can select temporary leaders to start operations, including staff hiring. The Commission can meet after the initial meeting with a quorum of four members, and vacancies do not affect its functioning. Any vacancy on the Financial Markets Commission will not affect its powers, and it will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Financial Markets Commission's powers are not affected by vacancies, which will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Financial Markets Commission's functions include examining causes of the financial crisis in the US and investigating the roles of various entities like the SEC, rating organizations, and trading facilities. The Financial Markets Commission investigates entities such as trading facilities, self-regulatory organizations, Federal banking agencies, financial corporations, and governmental entities. They are required to submit reports and refer any relevant individuals to the Attorney General. The Financial Markets Commission investigates entities and refers relevant individuals to the Attorney General if they may have violated US laws related to a crisis. The Financial Markets Commission investigates entities and refers relevant individuals to the Attorney General if they may have violated US laws related to a crisis. SEC. 5. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Financial Markets Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and issue subpoenas to gather evidence for carrying out its duties under the Act. Subpoenas can be enforced through the United States district court in case of non-compliance. The Financial Markets Commission can issue orders for individuals to testify or produce evidence, with non-compliance punishable by contempt of court. Additional enforcement measures apply for witnesses failing to comply. The Commission is authorized to enter into contracts to fulfill its responsibilities, and can obtain information from federal agencies. The Financial Markets Commission can obtain information directly from federal agencies to support its inquiries and functions. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to provide necessary funding and administrative support to the Commission. The Financial Markets Commission can receive up to $3,000,000 from the Treasury. Other US departments and agencies can also offer assistance, funds, and services to the Commission. The Commission is allowed to accept gifts, use postal services, and authorize subcommittees, members, or agents to take actions on its behalf. SEC. 6. STAFF OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. Additional staff may be appointed as needed without following certain civil service laws. Staff may be paid up to the equivalent of level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can appoint individuals as employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission can also procure consultant services at rates not exceeding those of a level IV position in the Executive Schedule. SEC. 7. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES.

Each Commission member may be compensated at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also allowed travel expenses while performing Commission duties.

SEC. 8. REPORTS OF THE COMMISSION; TERMINATION. The Commission is required to submit a final report to the President and Congress within 1 year of its first meeting, detailing the causes of the financial crisis and recommending statutory changes. Interim reports can also be submitted with agreed-upon corrective measures. The Commission, along with all its authorities, will terminate 60 days after submitting the final report. During this period, the Commission can conclude its activities, testify before Congress, and disseminate the final report.
